Ohdo syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects multiple systems of the body, including the eyes, ears, mouth, and brain. It is characterized by symptoms such as drooping eyelids (blepharophimosis), difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), hearing loss, dental abnormalities, and intellectual disability. The exact cause of Ohdo syndrome is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. There is no cure for Ohdo syndrome, but treatment can help manage the symptoms.

Blepharophimosis, intellectual disability syndrome (SBBYS) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the muscles responsible for eyelid movements. It is characterized by drooping eyelids (ptosis), which can obstruct vision and lead to difficulties in eating or breathing. Additionally, affected individuals may experience intellectual disability and other developmental delays. The exact cause of SBBYS is not yet fully understood, but it is believed to be due to a mutation in the MSH3 gene, which is involved in DNA repair. Treatment for SBBYS typically involves surgery to correct the ptosis and improve eyelid function.

Oculodentodigital dysplasia, also known as ODD syndrome, is a rare genetic disorder that affects multiple systems of the body. It is characterized by craniofacial abnormalities such as a high or broad forehead, large eyes with long eyelashes, and an underbite (referred to as mandibular prognathism).

Neurological problems can include developmental delay, seizures, and muscular hypotonia. Additionally, limb abnormalities such as polydactyly (extra fingers or toes) and clubfoot may be present. Oculodentodigital dysplasia is also associated with eye abnormalities like ocular hypertelorism (wide-set eyes), ectopia lentis (dislocated lenses), and a coloboma (a missing part of the iris).

Overall, this condition can cause significant challenges for affected individuals due to its multifaceted nature. It is important for people with Oculodentodigital dysplasia to receive proper medical care, including regular check-ups and specialized treatments as needed.

It has material basis in X-linked recessive inheritance and is associated with vitamin K-related teratogenicity.

Autosomal dominant chondrodysplasia punctata is a type of genetic disorder that is passed down through families and affects multiple organ systems in the body, with predominance on the long bones of the limbs. It is characterized by abnormal facies and stippling of the limbs, associated with vitamin K-related teratogenicity.

Cold-induced sweating syndrome, also known as Crisponi syndrome or Sohar-Crisponi syndrome, is a type of autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by profuse sweating induced by cold ambient temperature. It is important to note that this condition has a material basis in genetic inheritance and is not simply the result of exposure to cold temperatures. The exact cause of this syndrome is unknown, but it is believed to be related to abnormalities in the body's ability to regulate temperature.

Complement component 2 deficiency is a type of complement deficiency characterized by recurrent bacterial infections. It has a material basis in autosomal recessive inheritance of mutation in the C2 gene.

Congenital Secretory Chloride Diarrhea 1 is a type of secretory diarrhea that has a material basis in mutations in the SLC26A3 gene. It is an autosomal recessive disease and can be considered as a physical disorder. This condition affects the normal functioning of the intestines, causing excessive salt and water secretion, leading to diarrhea. The symptoms may include watery diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and cramping. It is important for those affected by this condition to work with a healthcare professional to manage their symptoms effectively.

Complement component 4a deficiency is a condition where the body lacks enough of the complement component 4a, which is part of the immune system. This can lead to an increased risk of recurrent bacterial infections.

Complement component 4b deficiency, also known as C4B deficiency, is a type of complement deficiency that can lead to recurrent bacterial infections due to the reduced activity of complement component 4b. It is important for individuals with this condition to work closely with their healthcare providers to manage their condition and reduce the risk of infections.

C6 deficiency, also known as complement component 6 deficiency or CC6D, is a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to fight infections. It occurs when there are problems with the C6 gene, which is responsible for producing the C6 protein. This protein is an essential part of the complement system, which helps the immune system identify and destroy harmful bacteria, viruses, and fungi.
When someone has C6 deficiency, they may be more susceptible to recurrent bacterial infections, particularly those caused by certain types of bacteria such as Neisseria meningitidis and Streptococcus pneumoniae. In some cases, people with C6 deficiency may also experience autoimmune reactions or develop antibodies against their own body tissues.
Diagnosis of C6 deficiency is typically made through blood tests that measure the levels of complement proteins in the blood. Treatment usually involves antibiotics to prevent and treat infections, as well as other medications to manage symptoms such as fever and inflammation. In some cases, a plasma exchange or intravenous immunoglobulin therapy may also be used to help boost the immune system.
Overall, while C6 deficiency can make it more difficult for the body to fight infections, with proper treatment and care, people with this condition can still lead healthy lives.

C7 deficiency, also known as complement component 7 (CC7) deficiency or properdin deficiency, is a rare genetic disorder that results from mutations in the C7 gene. It is one of several types of complement component deficiencies, which can lead to an increased susceptibility to bacterial infections.

People with CC7 deficiency have low levels of properdin, a protein that plays a crucial role in the activation and function of the complement system. This can make it difficult for the body to fight off certain types of bacteria, increasing the risk of recurrent infections, particularly in the ears, lungs, and sinuses.

Diagnosis of CC7 deficiency typically involves a combination of medical history, physical examination, and laboratory tests. These may include measuring properdin levels, testing for complement function, and identifying specific genetic mutations. Treatment options depend on the severity of the deficiency and the underlying cause but may involve medications to boost the immune system or prevent infections.

It is important to note that not all individuals with CC7 deficiency will experience recurrent infections, and some may never develop any symptoms at all. However, for those who do suffer from persistent infections, early diagnosis and appropriate treatment can significantly improve their quality of life and reduce the risk of long-term complications.

Complement component 8 (C8) is an essential part of the complement system, which plays a crucial role in the immune response against pathogens. Complement component 8 is composed of two subunits, alpha and beta, which work together to form the membrane attack complex (MAC), which helps to lyse (break down) the cell walls of bacteria, fungi, and other pathogens.
Type I complement deficiency occurs when there is a lack of one or more complement components in the serum. Complement component 8 (C8) deficiency is a specific type of complement deficiency characterized by a deficiency of the alpha subunit of complement protein 8, which results in decreased levels of functional C8 in the serum. This can lead to increased susceptibility to recurrent bacterial infections, especially to Neisseria meningitidis.
Complement component 8 (C8) deficiency is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning that a person must inherit two copies of the faulty gene (one from each parent) to develop the condition. The C8A gene, which codes for the alpha subunit of complement protein 8, can be mutated, resulting in the production of a non-functional protein.
Overall, Complement component 8 (C8) deficiency is an inherited disorder that can lead to increased susceptibility to bacterial infections, and it is important to manage the condition carefully to prevent complications.

Type II complement component 8 deficiency is a type of complement deficiency that occurs due to a lack of the beta subunit of complement protein 8. This deficiency causes susceptibility to recurrent bacterial infections, particularly Neisseria meningitidis. The genetic basis for this deficiency is autosomal recessive inheritance of mutation in the C8B gene, which produces the beta subunit of complement component 8. This component plays an important role in forming the membrane attack complexes.
complement component 9 deficiency is a type of complement deficiency that is characterized by recurrent bacterial infections. It has a material basis in mutations in the C9 gene.

dyschromatosis universalis hereditaria is a type of pigmentation disease.

Megalocornea is a type of corneal disease that is characterized by an enlarged corneal diameter without an increase in intraocular pressure, and it has a material basis in mutation of the CHRDL1 gene. It can also be referred to as anterior megalophthalmos or congenital anterior megalophthmia.

Meier Gorlin Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects multiple organ systems, primarily the ear and the skeletal system. It is characterized by bilateral underdevelopment of the external ear (also known as microtia), short stature, absent or underdeveloped patellae, and severe prenatal and postnatal growth retardation. The disorder is caused by mutations in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene, which leads to abnormal development of bone and cartilage. Symptoms typically become evident in early childhood, and management may involve surgical interventions to correct deformities or hearing aids for any associated hearing issues.

Autosomal dominant intellectual developmental disorder is a type of autosomal dominant disease that is characterized by an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and intellectual disability. It is also known as autosomal dominant mental retardation or autosomal dominant non-syndromic mental retardation.

Autosomal recessive intellectual developmental disorder (ARIDD) is a type of autosomal recessive disease where the inheritance pattern is passed down through the autosomes (non-sex chromosomes). It leads to intellectual disability, which can affect an individual's cognitive abilities, such as problem-solving, memory, and language skills. ARIDD has a material basis in genetic mutations that occur on these autosomal chromosomes.

There is no specific name for this condition; however, it may be referred to as autosomal recessive intellectual disability or non-syndromic mental retardation when discussing the inheritance pattern and symptoms associated with the condition. It's important to note that ARIDD can occur in individuals of any race or ethnicity.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability is a type of intellectual disability that is characterized by an X-linked inheritance pattern. It is also known as syndromic X-linked mental retardation, and it has a material basis in some X-linked inheritance.

uvulitis is a condition characterized by the inflammation and swelling of the uvula, which is the small fleshy structure hanging from the soft palate in the back of the mouth. It is commonly caused by viral infections or allergies and can cause symptoms such as hoarseness, difficulty swallowing, and a feeling of something being stuck in the throat. Acute uvulitis refers to a sudden and severe inflammation of the uvula, which can occur due to factors such as vocal strain or exposure to irritants. Treatment for uvulitis typically involves medications to reduce inflammation and swelling, as well as measures to prevent further irritation or injury to the throat.

Adenoid hypertrophy is a type of upper respiratory tract disease characterized by the unusual growth of the adenoid tonsil. This condition can cause symptoms such as snoring, hyponasality, otitis media with effusion, and mouth breathing. The exact synonyms for this condition include adenoidal hypertrophy and enlarged adenoids.

Angular cheilitis is a type of cheilitis that causes inflammation in the corners of the mouth. It is also known as angular cheilosis or angular stomatitis, and it can be caused by poor dental hygiene, infections, or irritants such as tobacco use. Symptoms may include pain or discomfort in the affected areas, cracking or bleeding of the lips, and difficulty opening the mouth. Treatment options may include topical creams, antibiotics, or surgery in severe cases.

Congenital tracheomalacia is a type of tracheal disease that occurs due to abnormalities in the development of the trachea during fetal life. It results in weakened or flaccid tracheal cartilage, which can lead to difficulty breathing and other respiratory problems in newborns. Treatment typically involves surgery to strengthen the tracheal wall and improve airflow.

Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy (PGL) is a condition characterized by enlarged, non-painful lymph nodes that persist for more than three to six months without an identifiable cause. It can be considered as the same thing as Generalized Lymphadenopathy (GLA). PGL can affect people of all ages and is often found in combination with other health issues such as HIV or cancer. Treatment options depend on the underlying cause but may include medications, immunotherapy, and surgery.

oral hairy leukoplakia is a type of mouth disease.

oral hairy leukoplakia has exact synonym hairy leukoplakia.

Orofaciodigital syndrome type I is a genetic disorder that affects the development of various body parts. It is caused by mutations in the X-linked dominant OFD1 gene, which is located on the X chromosome. Males are usually more severely affected than females due to the way the X chromosome works. The symptoms can include cystic kidneys, facial abnormalities, oral cavity issues, and digit malformations. There is no cure for this condition, but treatment may be available to manage the symptoms.

Lung abscess is a type of lung disease that is characterized by the presence of microbial infections, leading to liquefactive necrosis of the pulmonary tissue and the formation of cavities containing necrotic debris or fluid.

acute promyelocytic leukemia is a type of acute myeloid leukemia.
acute promyelocytic leukemia has definition An acute myeloid leukemia characterized by accumulation of promyelocytes in the bone marrow and by a translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17..
acute promyelocytic leukemia has exact synonyms acute myeloblastic leukaemia type 3, acute myeloid leukemia M3 and acute promyelocytic leukaemia.

Cardiac arrest is a medical emergency that occurs when the heart suddenly stops beating or has difficulty pumping blood to the body. It can lead to a sudden loss of consciousness and, if not treated promptly, can be fatal. Cardiac arrest is often used interchangeably with cardiopulmonary arrest, which refers to the cessation of both the heart's ability to pump blood and the lungs' ability to oxygenate blood. Circulatory arrest, on the other hand, specifically refers to the cessation of blood flow due to a blockage or obstruction in the circulatory system. While all three terms are related to disruptions in blood flow, they serve to differentiate between different underlying causes and treatment approaches.

That is correct. Inguinal hernia occurs when a part of the intestine protrudes through the inguinal canal, which is located in the groin area. It can cause discomfort and pain, and if left untreated, it can lead to serious complications such as bowel obstruction or strangulation. Treatment options for inguinal hernia include surgery and lifestyle changes to prevent future complications.

Umbilical hernia is a condition in which part of the intestine protrudes through an opening in the abdominal muscles. This can occur when there is weakness or damage to these muscles, or if there is increased pressure in the abdomen. It is common during pregnancy and childbirth, but can also occur in infants and adults. The protruding intestine can be gently pushed back into the abdomen, but surgery may be necessary to repair any damaged muscles or to prevent complications such as strangulation.
Mastoiditis is a type of middle ear disease characterized by inflammation of the mucosal lining of the mastoid antrum and the mastoid air cell system inside the mastoid process.
Breast abscess is a type of breast disease. It is characterized by the presence of pus in the breast tissue.

Tooth Abscess is a common dental condition that occurs when the pulp chamber of a tooth becomes infected. This infection can lead to inflammation and swelling around the affected tooth, which may cause pain or discomfort. In some cases, an abscess can also develop into a more serious condition called a pericoronitis, which involves inflammation of the tissues surrounding the root tip of the tooth.
Dental abscesses are typically treated with antibiotics and may require additional procedures such as a root canal or tooth extraction if the infection is severe enough. It is important to consult a dentist promptly if you experience symptoms of a dental abscess, as early treatment can help prevent complications and save your natural teeth.
Cervical polyp is a type of cervix disease characterized by the presence of a benign polyp on the surface of the cervical canal.

Myelomeningocele (MMC) is a type of spina bifida where the spinal cord and meninges protrude through an opening in the vertebrae. It occurs when the neural tube fails to close properly during fetal development, leading to the exposure of the spinal cord and surrounding structures.
Symptoms can vary widely, but may include motor and sensory loss, bladder and bowel dysfunction, and spasticity. Treatment typically involves surgery to correct the protrusion of the spinal cord and meninges, as well as management of any associated complications such as hydrocephalus or infection. With proper treatment and care, many individuals with MMC can lead full and productive lives.

Omphalocele is a birth defect that occurs when the intestines, liver, and other organs protrude through an abnormal opening in the belly button. It is caused by a weakness in the muscles of the abdominal wall, which can occur due to genetic factors or exposure to certain medications during pregnancy. Omphalocele can be diagnosed through physical examination and imaging tests such as ultrasound or CT scan. Treatment options include surgical repair, which aims to return the organs to their proper position within the abdomen and close the opening in the belly button. In some cases, non-surgical management may also be considered. It's important for individuals with omphalocele to work closely with their healthcare provider to develop a personalized treatment plan that addresses their specific needs and concerns.

An anal fistula is a narrow tube-like channel that forms between the skin near the anus and the anal canal. It results from an infection or inflammation in the gastrointestinal tract, often due to a small tear or abscess in the anal canal. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, itching, and discharge of pus or mucus. Treatment options may include antibiotics, analgesics, and surgery. It is essential to consult a medical professional for proper diagnosis and treatment.

Ectopic pregnancy is a serious medical condition that occurs when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, typically in a fallopian tube. This can be a life-threatening situation if not treated promptly and properly. Symptoms of ectopic pregnancy may include abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and shoulder pain. It is important to seek medical attention immediately if these symptoms are present. Ectopic pregnancies can be diagnosed through a combination of physical exams, blood tests, and imaging studies such as ultrasounds. Treatment options may include medication to dissolve the fertilized egg or surgery to remove it. It is crucial to consult a healthcare professional for proper evaluation and management of this condition.

Rapp-Hodgkin Syndrome (RHS) is a type of ectodermal dysplasia, which refers to abnormal development of the ectodermal tissues including the skin, hair, nails, teeth, and sweat glands. RHS is characterized by anhidrotic ectodermal dysplasia, which means that the patient is unable to sweat, as well as cleft lip/palate. It is a type of autosomal dominant disease, which means that it is passed down through families and can affect any member of the family.

Mitochondrial complex V (ATP synthase) deficiency is a rare genetic disorder that affects the function of the ATP synthase, which is an enzyme that produces ATP (adenosine triphosphate), a molecule that provides energy to cells. When this enzyme is not working properly due to a mutation in one of the genes that encode for it, cells are unable to produce sufficient ATP and may not be able to function properly, leading to a variety of symptoms and health problems.

Mitochondrial complex V (ATP synthase) deficiency can be inherited or acquired and can affect different tissues in the body, including the brain, heart, muscles, and liver. It is often diagnosed in infancy or early childhood and can cause a variety of symptoms such as poor growth, developmental delays, lethargy, weakness, exercise intolerance, cramping, and seizures. In severe cases, it can be life-threatening.

Treatment for mitochondrial complex V (ATP synthase) deficiency typically focuses on managing symptoms and providing supportive care to improve the quality of life. This may include medications to manage seizures, antioxidants to protect cells from damage, and dietary changes to provide adequate nutrition. In some cases, a pacemaker may be needed to regulate heart function in individuals with heart problems.

Genetic counseling and testing are important for families who have a history of the disorder or for those who are considering having children. With proper treatment and management, people with mitochondrial complex V (ATP synthase) deficiency can lead fulfilling lives.

Mitochondrial complex V (ATP synthase) deficiency, nuclear type 3 is a rare genetic disorder that affects the mitochondria in the body. It occurs due to mutations in the ATP5E gene on chromosome 20q13. This leads to a deficiency in the complex V of the ATP synthase, which is responsible for generating ATP (adenosine triphosphate) - the energy currency of the cell. As a result, cells may not have enough energy to function properly and can lead to various symptoms such as muscle weakness, fatigue, and respiratory failure. Treatment options depend on the severity of the symptoms but may include supplements, dietary changes, and medication.

Mitochondrial complex V (ATP synthase) deficiency, nuclear type 4, is a specific form of mitochondrial complex V (ATP synthase) deficiency that has a basis in mutations in the ATP5F1A gene on chromosome 18q21.1. It is also known as MC5DN4.

Transient neonatal diabetes mellitus is a type of neonatal diabetes that is characterized by high blood sugar levels during the newborn period, which typically resolves during infancy but recurs later in life for most patients.

Autosomal dominant sideroblastic anemia 4 (SDA4) is a type of sideroblastic anemia. Sideroblastic anemia refers to a group of anemias characterized by the inability of the body to produce red blood cells or hemoglobin. In autosomal dominant inheritance, a person inherits a gene from one or both parents that causes the disease.
The inheritance pattern means that if one parent passes on the gene for SDA4, there is a 50% chance that their child will inherit and develop the condition. This is different from a recessive trait, where both parents must pass on the gene for the child to have a full risk of developing the disease.
SDA4 affects the formation of red blood cells by causing abnormalities in the process called sideroblastic anemia, which is characterized by insufficient production or accumulation of ring-shaped iron particles (called mitochondria) in the bone marrow, leading to the formation of microscopic, nonfunctional red blood cells.
It's important for individuals who suspect they have SDA4 to consult with a healthcare professional for accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

3-methylglutaconic aciduria is a type of organic aciduria, where there are abnormal levels of 3-methylglutaconic and 3-methylglutaric acids in the urine. It is caused by genetic mutations that affect the metabolism of these compounds. Symptoms can include developmental delays, seizures, and muscle stiffness. Treatment typically involves a low-protein diet and medication to help manage symptoms.

Cednik Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects many different organ systems in the body, primarily involving the brain and skin. It is caused by mutations in the SNAP29 gene on the X chromosome, which leads to a unique combination of symptoms including microcephaly (small head), severe neurologic impairment, psychomotor retardation, failure to thrive, facial dysmorphism, palmoplantar keratoderma and late-onset ichthyosis. The syndrome has a material basis in homozygous mutation in the SNAP29 gene and characterized by a unique constellation of clinical manifestations including microcephaly, severe neurologic impairment, psychomotor retardation, failure to thrive, facial dysmoprhism, palmoplantar keratoderma and late-onset ichthyosis. Cednik Syndrome has exact synonyms of cerebral dysgenesis, neuropathy, ichthyosis and keratoderma syndrome.

Parameningeal embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma is a specific type of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma that occurs in the parameningeal region, which includes the meninges and other structures around the brain. It is characterized by the presence of muscle cells that have not yet developed into functional muscles.

CAID syndrome, also known as chronic atrial and intestinal dysrhythmia, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a unique combination of cardiac arrhythmias and intestinal pseudo-obstruction. It is caused by mutations in the SGOL1 protein, which leads to abnormalities in the heart's electrical activity and impairment of normal muscle function in the small intestine.

Clinically, CAID syndrome presents with atrial dysrhythmias, such as sick sinus syndrome (SSS) and valve anomalies, along with chronic intestinal pseudo-obstruction (CIPO). The syndrome can also be associated with other gastrointestinal and systemic manifestations.

Diagnosis of CAID syndrome typically involves a combination of clinical presentation, genetic testing, electrocardiography, and gastrointopy with manometry. Treatment options for the disorder may include medication to manage arrhythmias, surgery to address CIPO, and nutritional support as needed.

Overall, CAID syndrome is a complex genetic disorder that requires a multidisciplinary approach to management, with input from cardiologists, gastroenterologists, genetic counselors, and other healthcare professionals.

Ciliopathy is a type of monogenic disease characterized by the presence of mutations in genes that encode for proteins involved in cilia function. These mutations can result in abnormalities in cilia formation or function, leading to a range of developmental and functional defects. Ciliopathies are a group of disorders that affect the cilia, which are microtubule-based structures that play an essential role in many cellular processes such as motility, signaling, and morphogenesis. They can be inherited or acquired, and can affect various organ systems including the respiratory, cardiovascular, and reproductive systems.

Agnathia otocephaly complex is a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the face and jaw. It is characterized by mandibular hypoplasia or agnathia, ventromedial auricular malposition (melotia) and/or auricular fusion (synotia), microstomia with oroglossal hypoplasia or aglossia, and holoprosencephaly. Other anomalies such as skeletal, genitourinary and cardiovascular issues, and situs inversus have also been reported in some cases. The disorder is often associated with other conditions like dysgnathia complex, agnathia-holoprosencephaly, holoprosencephaly-agnathia, otocephaly, and dysgnathia complex agnathia-holoprosencephaly.
acromelic frontonasal dysostosis is a type of autosomal dominant disease.

glucocorticoid induced osteoporosis is a type of osteoporosis that is caused by long-term use of glucocorticoids. It can cause the bones to become weak and brittle, increasing the risk of fractures. Symptoms may include a loss of height, back pain, and an increased risk of breaking bones. Treatment options for glucocorticoid induced osteoporosis include medications to slow down bone loss, as well as lifestyle changes such as weight-bearing exercises and adequate calcium intake through diet or supplements.

acrodermatitis chronica atrophicans is a skin condition that results from the progression of acrodermatitis. It is characterized by widespread atrophy of the skin, and it can be caused by Lyme borreliosis. This condition is also known as Herxheimer disease or primary diffuse atrophy.

Bacillary angiomatosis is a type of bartonellosis characterized by the proliferation of blood vessels, resulting in them forming tumor-like masses in the skin and other organs. It has a material basis in either Bartonella henselae or Bartonella quintana.

Native American myopathy, also known as Bailey-Bloch congenital myopathy, is a type of autosomal recessive disease that affects muscle strength and causes various physical abnormalities. It is characterized by congenital weakness, arthrogryposis, cleft palate, ptosis, myopathic facies, short stature, kyphoscoliosis, talipes deformities, and susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia during anesthesia. It is caused by a homozygous mutation in the STAC3 gene on chromosome 12q13.

Acro renal syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects multiple organ systems. It is caused by a mutation in one of several genes that are involved in the development of the kidneys, limbs, and other body structures. The severity of the condition can vary greatly depending on which genes are affected and which body parts are involved. Some people with acro renal syndrome may have only mild symptoms or none at all, while others may experience a range of health problems, including:

* Limb deformities such as cleft hands or feet
* Renal agenesis (absence of one or both kidneys)
* Renal hypoplasia (underdevelopment of one or both kidneys)
* Polycystic kidney disease (multiple cysts in the kidneys)
* Other organ malformations such as tracheo-esophageal fistula, congenital heart defects, and skeletal abnormalities.

Treatment for acro renal syndrome depends on the specific symptoms and severity of the condition. In some cases, surgery may be necessary to correct limb deformities or address other health problems. Dialysis or a kidney transplant may also be required if the affected kidneys are not functioning properly.

It is important for individuals with acro renal syndrome to work closely with their healthcare providers to manage their symptoms and ensure proper treatment. Genetic counseling can also be beneficial for families of people with the condition, as it can help provide information about the risk of recurrence and potential options for future pregnancies.

Hypoparathyroidism, retardation, dysmorphism syndrome (HRD syndrome) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the parathyroid glands and brain. It is characterized by permanent parathyroid hormone (PTH) deficiency, hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, facial anomalies, and psychomotor retardation. The disorder has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the TBCE gene on chromosome 1q42.3. It is also known as Sanjad-Sakati syndrome, HRD syndrome and hypoparathyroidism with short stature, mental retardation, and seizures.
Microcephaly with or without chorioretinopathy, lymphedema, or mental retardation is a type of autosomal dominant disease.

Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRT) deficiency is a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to produce adenine, a purine base found in DNA and RNA. The deficiency results from a lack of APRT enzyme activity, which leads to an excessive accumulation of 2,8-dihydroxyadenine (DHA) in various tissues, including the kidneys. DHA stones can form in the urinary tract and may cause renal failure if left untreated. APRT deficiency is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning that a person must inherit two copies of the gene (one from each parent) to develop the disorder.

Mitochondrial complex III deficiency, nuclear type 2 is a rare genetic disorder that affects the mitochondria, which are the energy-producing structures in our cells. It is characterized by motor disability, ataxia, apraxia, dystonia, and dysarthria, as well as necrotic lesions throughout the brain. The disorder has a basis in a structural variant of the TTC19 gene on chromosome 17, and it is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

Kleefstra syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects development in many ways. It is caused by a deletion or mutation of the EHMT1 gene on chromosome 9, which is located at the q34 region. This disorder typically causes severe mental retardation and various physical characteristics, such as microcephaly (small head size), epileptic seizures, and heart defects. The symptoms of Kleefstra syndrome can range from mild to severe, depending on the extent of the gene deletion or mutation. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, which means that a single copy of the altered gene is enough to cause the disorder.

Acrofacial dysostosis Cincinnati type, also known as ACDC, is a genetic disorder characterized by the malformation of facial bones. It is caused by mutations in the POLR1A gene on chromosome 2p11, which results in a spectrum of mandibulofacial dysostosis phenotypes such as cleft palate, micrognathia, malar flattening, microcephaly and sometimes extrafacial skeletal defects. ACDC is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.

Stormorken syndrome, also known as thrombocytopathy with asplenia and miosis, is a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to produce healthy blood cells. It is caused by a mutation in the STM1 gene on chromosome 11p15, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. People with Stormorken syndrome may experience symptoms such as thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), mild anemia, asplenia (absence of the spleen), tubular aggregate myopathy, miosis (smaller pupils), headache, and ichthyosis. The condition is characterized by a combination of these symptoms, which can vary in severity from person to person.

amyotrophic lateral sclerosis type 22 is a specific subtype of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, characterized by mutations in the TUBA4A gene located on chromosome 2q35. It is also known as ALS 22 or amyotrohpic lateral sclerosis 22 with or without frontotemporal dementia.

Vici Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the absence of the corpus callosum, cataracts, cardiomyopathy, combined immunodeficiency and hypopigmentation. It is caused by mutations in the EPG5 gene on chromosome 18q12.3 and has material basis in autosomal recessive inheritance. The disorder has an exact synonym of Immunodeficiency with cleft lip/palate, cataract, hypopigmentation, and absent corpus callosum.

Chylomicron retention disease is a type of lipid metabolism disorder that occurs when the body has difficulty processing fats and cholesterol. It can cause malnutrition, growth failure, and other health problems if left untreated. The condition is usually inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, and it has a material basis in mutations in the SAR1B gene on chromosome 5q31.1. It's also known by its exact synonyms Anderson disease and CMRD.

Multiple Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency (MADD) is a genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to break down proteins and fats for energy. It has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, which means that in order for an individual to develop the disease, both of their parents must pass on the gene mutation. This condition is caused by mutations in the ETFA, ETFB, and ETFDH genes and can present with three different clinical phenotypes: a neonatal-onset form with congenital anomalies (type I), a neonatal-onset form without congenital anomalies (type II), and a late-onset form (type III). Atrichia with papular lesions is a type of autosomal recessive disease, characterized by the loss of hair during the neonatal period on all areas of the body that bear hair, followed by the development of papular lesions all over the body. This condition has a material basis in mutations in the HR gene on chromosome 8p21.3. The term "Atrichia with papular lesions" is often used interchangeably with "papular atrichia."

Autosomal dominant auditory neuropathy 1 (AUNA1) is a type of autosomal dominant nonsyndromic deafness, characterized by the preservation of outer hair cell function and abnormal or absent auditory brainstem responses. It has a genetic basis, with mutations in the DIAPH3 gene on chromosome 13q being responsible for this condition. AUNA1 is also known as nonsyndromic dominant auditory neuropathy (NSDAN).

Platelet type bleeding disorder 16, also known as Glanzmann thrombasthenia, is a rare genetic condition characterized by autosomal dominant inheritance. It affects the blood platelets and can cause prolonged bleeding time but only mildly increased bleeding tendency. The disease has a material basis in heterozygous mutation in the ITGA2B gene on chromosome 17q21.31 or the ITGB3 gene on chromosome 17q21.32.

Platelet Type Bleeding Disorder 8 is a type of autosomal recessive blood platelet disease characterized by mild to moderate mucocutaneous bleeding and absence of adenosine phosphate induced platelet aggregation that has material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutation in the P2RY12 gene on chromosome 3q.

Brunner syndrome is a type of amino acid metabolic disorder that occurs due to a recessive X-linked inheritance. It is characterized by impaired monoamine metabolism, impulsive aggression and mild mental retardation. Brunner syndrome has material basis in mutations in the MAOA gene on chromosome Xp11. It is also known as monoamine oxidase A deficiency.

Cayman type cerebellar ataxia is a specific form of autosomal recessive cerebellar ataxia that is characterized by certain symptoms such as psychomotor retardation, cerebellar dysfunction including nystagmus, intention tremor, dysarthria, and wide-based ataxic gait, hypotonia, and the absence of retinal abnormalities. It has a genetic basis and is caused by mutations in the ATCAY gene on chromosome 19p13.3. This condition is also known as Cayman cerebellar ataxia.

Hyperekplexia is a type of nervous system disease characterized by an exaggerated startle response to sudden, unexpected auditory or tactile stimuli and hypertonia. It also has the exact synonyms Kok disease, congenital stiff man syndrome, familial startle disease, hereditary hyperekplexia, and startle disease. Additionally, it has a match with GARD:3129.

Hyperekplexia 1 is a type of autosomal dominant disease. It is caused by mutations in the GLRA1 gene on chromosome 5q32. Heterozygous, homozygous, or compound heterozygous mutations in this gene can lead to the development of hyperekplexia 1. The term "hyperekplexia" refers to a neurological disorder characterized by muscle rigidity and difficulty with voluntary movements. HKPX1 is an exact synonym for hyperekplexia 1, indicating that they are the same condition.

Hyperekplexia 2, also known as HKPX2, is a type of autosomal recessive disease. It is characterized by a hyperekplexia, which is a sudden loss of balance or stiffness in the limbs, often triggered by certain movements or positions. This condition has a material basis in compound heterozygous or homozygous mutation in the GLRB gene on chromosome 4q32. It's important to note that autosomal recessive diseases are genetic disorders that occur when an individual inherits two copies of a recessive gene, one from each parent. These genes provide instructions for making proteins that are necessary for the body's proper functioning. In the case of HKPX2, the mutated gene results in the production of abnormal or missing proteins, which can lead to the development of the condition.

Hyperekplexia type 3, also known as HKPX3, is a condition that results from mutations in the SLC6A5 gene on chromosome 11p15. It is an autosomal dominant disease, which means that a person only needs to inherit one copy of the mutated gene to develop the condition. Alternatively, it can also be inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, where a person must inherit two copies of the mutated gene, one from each parent.
Hyperekplexia type 3 is characterized by muscle rigidity and exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, which can cause difficulties with movement and coordination. It can also lead to problems with balance and an increased risk of falls. In severe cases, it may result in intellectual disability and developmental delays.
Treatment for hyperekplexia type 3 is usually focused on managing symptoms and improving quality of life. Medications and physical therapy can help to improve muscle tone and coordination, while assistive devices such as wheelchairs and walkers may be necessary for mobility. In some cases, surgery may be considered to relieve pressure on the spinal cord or other affected areas.
Early diagnosis and intervention are crucial in managing the symptoms of hyperekplexia type 3 and improving quality of life. If you suspect that you or a loved one may have this condition, it is important to consult with a healthcare professional for proper evaluation and treatment.

Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FBH) is a type of autosomal dominant disease, characterized by an elevation in serum calcium levels and decreased urinary calcium excretion. It is caused by mutations in the TRPV6 gene, which encodes a calcium-activated chloride channel that plays a role in regulating intracellular calcium homeostasis. FBH is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner and can be associated with certain subclinical or clinical features, such as nephrolithiasis, hyperparathyroidism, and osteoporosis. It is important to distinguish FBH from other types of hypercalcemia, such as malignancy-associated hypercalcemia, which can have different underlying causes and treatment approaches.

familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia 1 is a type of familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia.
familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia 1 has definition A familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia that has_material_basis_in heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the CASR gene on chromosome 3q21..
familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia 1 has exact synonym FHH type 1.
familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia 1 has exact synonym HHC1.
familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia 1 has exact synonym familial benign hypercalcemia 1.
familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia 1 has exact synonym familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia type I.
familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia 1 has exact synonym hypocalciuric hypercalcemia type I.

Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH) is a condition that results from an inability to reabsorb calcium from the intestines. This can lead to high levels of calcium in the blood and urine, as well as potential complications such as kidney stones, constipation, and osteoporosis. There are several types of FHH, including FHH type 2, which is caused by a heterozygous mutation in the GNA11 gene on chromosome 19p13.

Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia type 3, also known as FHH type 3 or HHC3, is a condition characterized by high levels of calcium in the blood (hypercalcemia) due to a heterozygous mutation in the AP2S1 gene on chromosome 19q13. This form of familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia has the same clinical features as other types, including mild to moderate symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. It is important for people with this condition to work closely with their healthcare provider to manage their calcium levels and prevent complications related to high calcium levels in the blood.

Muenke syndrome is a type of craniosynostosis, which is a condition characterized by the premature fusion of skull bones. It is caused by a mutation in the FGFR3 gene on chromosome 4p16.3 and is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. The symptoms of Muenke syndrome include macrocephaly (large head), midfacial hypoplasia, developmental delay, and uni- or bicoronal synostosis. It is named after Dr. Michael Muenke who first described the condition in 1997.

Lymphoproliferative syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency disease, which means it occurs due to an abnormality in the immune system. This condition is characterized by immune dysregulation after a viral infection, particularly the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. The exact synonym for this condition is Combined immunodeficiency due to ITK deficiency.

X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome 1 (XLP1) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the immune system. It is characterized by severe immune dysregulation following a viral infection, which may present as severe or fatal mononucleosis, acquired hypogammaglobulinemia, hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, and/or malignant lymphoma. XLP1 is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern, which means that a mutation in the SH2D1A gene on chromosome Xq25 causes the disorder.

x-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome 2 (XLP2) is a genetic disorder that affects the immune system. It is caused by mutations in the XIAP gene, which is located on the X chromosome at position xq25. The condition leads to dysregulation of the immune system after viral infections and can result in symptoms such as lymphoid hyperplasia (increased number of white blood cells), hypogammaglobulinemia (low levels of antibodies), and splenomegaly (enlarged spleen). XLP2 is an inherited condition, with most cases being due to X-linked recessive inheritance.

Lymphoproliferative syndrome 1 is a rare genetic disorder that affects the immune system, causing various types of cancer to develop. It is caused by mutations in the ITK gene on chromosome 5q32 and typically presents during childhood with symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and swollen lymph nodes. The disorder can lead to a variety of complications including Hodgkin's disease, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and other types of cancer. Treatment options may include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, stem cell transplantation, and immunotherapy.

Lymphoproliferative syndrome 2, also known as CD27 deficiency or LPFS2, is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by persistent symptomatic Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)-associated viremia, hypogammaglobulinemia, and impairment in specific antibody function. It has a material basis in homozygous mutation of the CD27 gene on chromosome 12p13.

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis 2 is a type of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis, characterized by fine scales on the scalp, face, trunk and limbs, marked palmoplantar hyperlinearity, hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, mild hypergranulosis and thickened stratum corneum that has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutation in the ALOX12B gene on chromosome 17p13. It is also known as ARCI2, BROCQ congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma nonbullous form, NCIE1 and nonbullous congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma 1.

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis 3, also known as ARCI3 or lamellar ichthyosis 5, is a type of autosomal recessive congenital ichothyosis that is characterized by mild ichthyosis, fine scales on the scalp, face, trunk and limbs, dark brown adherent scales on the neck, elbow and knees, and hypohydrosis. This condition has a basis in an abnormality of prenatal development or birth and is caused by mutations in the ALOXE3 gene on chromosome 17p13.

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis 4a is a type of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis characterized by generalized ichthyosis and ectropion. It has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutation in the ABCA12 gene on chromosome 2q35. This condition can be referred to as ARCI4A, ICR2B, ichthyosis congenita IIB, and lamellar ichthyosis 2.

autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis 4b is a type of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis characterized by severe neonatal ichthyosis with bilateral ectropion and eclabium, flattened and rudimentary nose and ears, constricting bands around the extremities and frequently lethality during infancy that has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutation in the ABCA12 gene on chromosome 2q35. It also has other exact synonyms such as ARCI4B, harlequin ichthyosis, harlequin type ichthyosis congenita, and harlequin type ichthyosis fetalis.

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis 5 is a type of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis, which is characterized by fine white or greyish-white scales, hyperkeratosis, moderate acanthosis, and moderate parakeratosis. It has a material basis in homozygous mutation in the CYP4F22 gene on chromosome 19p13. The exact synonyms for Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis 5 are ARCI5 and autosomal recessive congenital nonlamellar and nonerythrodermic ichthyosis.

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis 6 (ARCI6) is a type of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis. This condition has a genetic basis and affects the skin, causing itchiness, thickness, and rough texture. It is characterized by generalized ichthyosis, hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and moderate acanthosis. The condition is caused by mutations in the NIPAL4 gene on chromosome 5q33. ARCI6 has an exact synonym of ARCI.

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis 7 (ARCI7) is a type of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis.
Congenital ichthyosis is a group of birth defects characterized by abnormal development or presence of the skin, which can result in dry, scaly skin that may be prone to infection.
ARCI7 specifically refers to a type of congenital ichthyosis where fine whitish scales, moderate to severe erythroderma (redness of the skin), compact hyperkeratosis, hypergranulosis, acanthosis and papillomatosis are present. These symptoms are thought to result from an abnormality in the chromosome region 12p11.2-q13.1.
It is important to note that ARCI7 is just one of several possible types of congenital ichthyosis, and other forms may have different characteristics or causes.

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis 8, also known as ARCI8 or lamellar ichthyosis 4, is a type of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis that is characterized by diffuse lamellar ichthyosis, slight facial erythema, hyperkeratosis, orthokeratosis, hypergranulosis, and acanthosis. It has a basis in a homozygous mutation in the LIPN gene on chromosome 10q23.

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis 9 is a type of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis that has a basis in abnormalities during prenatal development or birth. It is characterized by fine erythrodermic scales, palmoplantar hyperlinearity, thick orthohyperkeratosis, hypergranulosis, moderate acanthosis and mild alopecia. The condition has a material basis in homozygous mutation in the CERS3 gene on chromosome 15q26. It is also known as ARCI9.

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis 10 (ARCI10) is a type of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis. It is characterized by generalized ichthyosis, moderade erythroderma, palmoplantar keratoderma and hypergranulosis. This condition has a material basis in homozygous mutation in the PNPLA1 gene on chromosome 6p21.

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis 11, also known as IFAH syndrome or IHS, is a genetic disorder characterized by skin peeling, hair loss, sensitivity to sunlight, and other skin-related issues. This condition is caused by mutations in the ST14 gene on chromosome 11q24. It has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance, which means that a person must inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disorder. Symptoms often appear within the first year of life and can be severe if not properly managed. Treatment may include emollients, vitamin supplements, and phototherapy.

ngly1 deficiency is a type of autosomal recessive disease where the body is unable to produce N-glycanase 1, which is an enzyme that helps in the process of glycosylation. This leads to the accumulation of incorrect or incomplete glycoproteins in the body and causes various developmental problems such as global developmental delay, hypotonia, abnormal involuntary movements, alacrima (poor tear production) and other related issues. The condition has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the NGLY1 gene on chromosome 1p24. It is also known as congenital disorder of deglycosylation type IV, deficiency of N-glycanase 1 and has exact synonyms like NGLY1-CDG and congenital disorder of glycosylation type Iv.

Torsion dystonia 1 is a type of autosomal dominant disorder that affects the muscles. It is characterized by involuntary and sustained muscle contractions, resulting in twisting movements or abnormal postures. This condition typically begins as focal, affecting specific body parts such as the limbs, but can progress to involve other areas of the body over time. Torsion dystonia 1 is caused by mutations in the TOR1A gene located on chromosome 9q34. The exact synonym for torsion dystonia 1 is "dystonia musculorum deformans."

Congenital central hypoventilation syndrome (CCHS) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, specifically in the respiratory center. It is characterized by reduced responsiveness of the respiratory center to carbon dioxide, diminished pupillary light responses, and other symptoms related to defects in the autonomic nervous system. The condition has a material basis in most commonly heterozygous mutation in the PHOX2B gene on chromosome 4p13, and less frequently mutations in the RET, GDNF, EDN3, BDNF, or ASCL1 genes.
CCHS can be diagnosed through a variety of tests, including genetic testing, neuroimaging, and pulmonary function tests. Treatment for CCHS may include medications to improve breathing, such as ventilators, and other therapies to manage symptoms. It is important to work with a healthcare professional to develop an individualized treatment plan for each person affected by this condition.

Chromosome 9p deletion syndrome, also known as Alfi Syndrome, is a rare genetic disorder that occurs due to the deletion of several genes on the short arm of chromosome 9. It is characterized by various physical and developmental abnormalities, such as trigonocephaly, flattened occiput, midface hypoplasia, long philtrum, prominent forehead, broad flat nasal bridge, anteverted nares, malformed external ears, hypertelorism, hypertonia, delayed psychomotor development, and other features. This disorder has a material basis in a contiguous gene deletion on the short arm of chromosome 9.

Junctional epidermolysis bullosa with pyloric atresia is a type of autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by the blistering of the skin at birth, along with congenital atresia of the pylorus and other portions of the gastrointestinal tract. It has been given various synonyms such as Carmi syndrome, JEB-PA, epidermolysis bullosa junctionalis with pyloric atresia, and junctional epidermolysis bullosa-pyloric atresia syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the ITGB4 or ITGA6 genes and has a material basis in autosomal recessive inheritance.
Epidermolysis bullosa simplex is a type of autosomal dominant skin disease.

Epidermolysis bullosa simplex ogna type is a type of epidermolysis bullosa simplex, which is a group of inherited disorders that primarily affect the skin. EBS-Og is another name for this condition, and it has a material basis in heterozygous mutations in the PLEC1 gene on chromosome 8q24. This condition causes skin blisters to form in the deepest areas of the basal cell cytoplasm just above the hemidesmosomes, as well as bruising of the skin.

Junctional epidermolysis bullosa Herlitz type is a severe and autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by the mutation of any one of three genes encoding the subunits of laminin-5 (LAMA3, LAMB3, and LAMC2), resulting in severe blisters and extensive erosions in the skin and mucous membranes. The Herlitz type is more severe than the non-Herlitz type of junctional epidermolysis bullosa and can lead to a failure to thrive, as well as other health issues. It has exact synonyms such as Herlitz type epidermolysis bullosa junctionalis, Herlitz-Pearson-type epidermolysis bullosa, JEB-H, JEB-Herlitz type, epidermolysis bullosa letalis, and junctional epidermolysis bullosa generalisata gravis.

Junctional epidermolysis bullosa non herlitz type is a type of autosomal recessive disease characterized by skin and mucosal blistering, nail dystrophy or nail absence, and enamel hypoplasia. It has material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutation in several genes including COL17A1, ITGB4 and the 3 genes that encode the subunits of laminin-5: LAMA3, LAMB3, and LAMC2. The non-Herlitz type is less severe than the related Herlitz type of junctional epidermolysis bullosa. It has synonyms such as generalized atrophic benign epidermolysis bullosa, junctional epidermolysis bullosa generalisata mitis, and disentis type.

Hand, Foot and Genital Syndrome (HFGS) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the extremities, urogenital system, and hand. It occurs due to mutations in the HOXA13 gene on chromosome 7p15. The condition is characterized by distal limb defects, including short thumbs and first toes, clinodactyly of the fifth fingers, delayed ossification of the wrist and ankle bones, urogenital defects, and other anomalies. HFGS has a predominantly autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

methylmalonic aciduria due to methylmalonyl coa mutase deficiency is a type of methylmalonic acidemia.
methylmalonic aciduria due to methylmalonyl coa mutase deficiency is a type of metabolic disorder that affects the body's ability to process certain amino acids. It occurs when there is a deficiency in the enzyme methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, which is responsible for converting methylmalonyl-CoA into succinyl-CoA. This can lead to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid in the blood and other tissues, causing a buildup of homocysteine and leading to symptoms such as vomiting, seizures, and developmental delays. Methylmalonic aciduria due to methylmalonyl coa mutase deficiency can be inherited or acquired and is usually diagnosed in infancy or childhood. Treatment may include dietary changes, vitamin supplements, and medications to manage symptoms.

Methylmalonic acidemia due to transcobalamin receptor defect is a type of methylmalonic acidemia that occurs when there is a mutation in the CD320 gene, which results in low uptake of transcobalamin-bound cobalamin. Despite normal conversion of cobalamin to adenosylcobalamin and methylcobalamin, this leads to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid. This type of methylmalonic acidemia is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. The exact synonyms for this condition are methylmalonic acidemia, TCblR type and methylmalonic aciduria due to transcobalamin receptor defect.

Methylmalonic acidemia (CblA type) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to metabolize certain amino acids. It is caused by mutations in the MMAA gene, which is located on chromosome 4q31. This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning that a person must inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disorder.

Symptoms of methylmalonic acidemia (CblA type) can include poor growth, developmental delays, lethargy, and a distinctive odor of burnt rubber in the breath. If left untreated, it can lead to severe complications such as brain damage, heart failure, and death.

Treatment for methylmalonic acidemia (CblA type) typically involves dietary restrictions, vitamin supplements, and enzyme replacement therapy. In some cases, liver transplantation may be necessary to treat related complications. It is important to seek medical attention if you suspect that your child has this disorder or if you are concerned about your own genetic risk factors.

Methylmalonic Acidemia (CblB Type) is a type of condition that has its basis in some structural variants.
Methylmalonic Acidemia (CblB Type) is characterized by autosomal recessive inheritance, defects in the synthesis of AdoCbl, vitamin B12 therapy responsiveness and has material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutation in the MMAB gene on chromosome 12q24.
Methylmalonic Acidemia (CblB Type) is identical to Methylmalonic Aciduria (CblB Type).
Methylmalonic Acidemia (CblB Type) is also known as Methylmalonic Aciduria, Vitamin B12-responsive, due to defect in synthesis of adenosylcobalamin, cblB complementation type.

Pendred syndrome is a type of autosomal recessive disease, characterized by bilateral prelingual sensorineural hearing loss and euthyroid goiter, and has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the SLC26A4 gene on chromosome 7q. It also has exact synonyms such as TDH2B, congenital hypothyroidism due to dyshormonogenesis 2B, deafness with goiter, genetic defect in thyroid hormonogenesis 2B, goiter-deafness syndrome, and thyroid dyshormonogenesis 2B.
Doyne honeycomb retinal dystrophy is a type of autosomal dominant disease.

Basal Laminar Drusen is a type of retinal drusen that has a genetic basis, characterized by yellow-white deposits (drusen) beneath the retinal pigment epithelium on Bruch membrane. These drusen are caused by mutations in the CFH gene on chromosome 1q31.3.

Duane Radial Ray Syndrome (DRS) is a rare congenital disorder characterized by distinctive facial features, hand abnormalities, and renal anomalies. It primarily affects males and is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. The condition is caused by mutations in the SALL4 gene located on chromosome 20q13.

DRS presents with a distinct facial appearance featuring a wide nasal bridge, prominent eyes (acromelophy), and a flat or slightly depressed midface. Hand abnormalities are also common, including radial ray malformations, which can result in limited thumb movement or absence of the thumbs. Renal anomalies may occur in some cases but are less severe compared to other congenital kidney diseases.

Unfortunately, there is no cure for DRS, and treatment options focus on managing the symptoms and improving the patient's quality of life. This may include orthopedic surgery to correct hand deformities or speech therapy to help with communication challenges.

familial temporal lobe epilepsy 1 is a type of autosomal dominant disease.
familial temporal lobe epilepsy 1 is a type of temporal lobe epilepsy that has material basis in autosomal dominant inheritance.
familial temporal lobe epilepsy 1 is characterized by partial seizures originating from the temporal lobe that are often accompanied by auditory symptoms and have_material_basis_in a heterozygous mutation in the LGI1 gene on chromosome 10q24.
familial temporal lobe epilepsy 1 has an exact synonym of ETL1.
familial temporal lobe epilepsy 1 has an exact synonym of partial epilepsy with auditory features.

Familial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy type 6 (ETL6) is a form of epilepsy that has a strong genetic component and is passed down through generations. It is characterized by recurrent seizures that originate in the temporal lobes of the brain, typically causing sensory or auditory hallucinations. The exact cause of ETL6 is not fully understood, but it has been linked to variations in the chromosome region 3q25-q26. There is no cure for this condition, but proper medical management and care can help control seizures and improve quality of life.

Familial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy Type 3, also known as FMTLE, is a form of autosomal dominant temporal lobe epilepsy. It is characterized by simple or complex partial seizures often accompanied by intense feelings of dj vu or altered awareness. The condition has a material basis in variations in the chromosome region 4q13.2-q21.3.

Familial temporal lobe epilepsy type 7 (ETL7) is a subtype of temporal lobe epilepsy that is characterized by autosomal dominant inheritance and seizures with prominent auditory symptoms. It has a material basis in heterozygous mutations in the RELN gene on chromosome 7q22. The exact synonym for ETL7 is familial temporal lobe epilepsy type 7.
familial temporal lobe epilepsy 5 is a type of autosomal dominant disease.

Familial temporal lobe epilepsy 4 is a type of autosomal dominant disease characterized by the inheritance of occipitotemporal lobe epilepsy and migraine with visual aura. It has a material basis in variation in the chromosome region 9q21-q22 and is also known as ETL4 or EPOLM.

Familial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy 8 (ETL8) is a type of autosomal dominant disease characterized by complex partial seizures with occasional secondary generalization and having a material basis in heterozygous mutation in the GAL gene on chromosome 11q13. It also has the exact synonym ETL8.
familial temporal lobe epilepsy 2 is a type of autosomal dominant disease.

sclerosteosis 1, also known as SOST1, is a type of autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the thickening of bones and cartilage. It occurs due to mutations in the SOST gene on chromosome 17q21.

Sclerosteosis 2, also known as SOST2, is a type of autosomal dominant disease. It occurs when someone inherits a mutated copy of the LRP4 gene on chromosome 11p11, which results in abnormalities in bone development and growth. This can lead to the formation of excessive bone tissue, causing bones to become denser and more brittle over time. Sclerosteosis 2 also affects cartilage, leading to ankylosis (the fusion of joint surfaces) and limited mobility in affected individuals. It is essential for medical professionals to diagnose this condition early on to provide proper treatment and management options.

immunodeficiency with hyper igm type 2 is a type of autosomal recessive disease that affects the immune system. It is characterized by low levels of immunoglobulin M (IgM) and normal or elevated levels of IgA, IgG, and IgE. This condition makes individuals with this disorder highly susceptible to bacterial infections. The exact cause of this disorder is not yet fully understood, but it has been linked to mutations in the AICDA gene on chromosome 12p13. There are several terms used to describe this condition, including HIGM2, activation-induced cytidine deaminase deficiency, and hyper-IgM syndrome type 2.
Hyper-IgM Syndrome Type 5, also known as Immunodeficiency with Hyper IgM Type 5

Hyper-IgM Syndrome Type 4, also known as Immunodeficiency with Hyper IgM Type 4, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by low or absent levels of immunoglobulins (antibodies) in the blood. This condition can make individuals more susceptible to infections and other illnesses. It is caused by mutations in the CBR2 gene, which is responsible for regulating the production of antibodies. Symptoms may include recurrent infections, developmental delays, and an increased risk of certain types of cancer. Treatment options may involve replacement therapy with intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and antibiotics to prevent and treat infections.

Familial chronic myelocytic leukemia-like syndrome (FCMLS) is a specific type of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) characterized by the presence of chronic myelocytic leukemia in early infancy and the absence of the BCR/ABL fusion gene (Philadelphia chromosome). It can also be referred to as familial CML-like syndrome.

Restrictive dermopathy is a rare and severe genetic disorder that affects the skin. It causes the skin to become thin, tightly adherent, translucent, and fragile with erosions at flexure sites. The disorder also affects blood vessels, causing superficial veins to be visible through the skin, and facial features may appear dysmorphic.

In addition to these skin and vessel abnormalities, restrictive dermopathy also causes joint ankylosis, which leads to severe restricted movement in the affected individual's joints. This can result in a shortened lifespan of just a few weeks for infants who are born with this disorder.

It is important to note that restrictive dermopathy has specific synonyms such as infantile restrictive dermopathy, lethal tight skin contracture syndrome, hyperkeratosis-contracture syndrome, and lethal restrictive dermopathy. The disorder is also known by other names including tight skin contracture syndrome, GARD:1516, MESH:C536920, OMIM:PS275210, ORDO:1662, SNOMEDCT_US_2023_02_28:400128006, and UMLS_CUI:C0406585.

Autosomal dominant Robinow syndrome 2 is a type of autosomal dominant disease. It is characterized by mesomelic limb shortening, genital hypoplasia, and distinctive facial features that have a material basis in heterozygous mutation in the DVL1 gene on chromosome 1p36. It has the exact synonym DRS2.

Autosomal dominant Robinow syndrome type 1 is a genetic disorder characterized by a range of physical and developmental abnormalities. It is caused by mutations in the WNT5A gene on chromosome 3p, which leads to dysmorphic features such as a "fetal face," short arms and legs, small genitals, and vertebral and renal anomalies. The inheritance of this disorder is autosomal dominant, meaning that only one copy of the mutated gene is needed for the condition to be passed on to offspring. It is also referred to as DRS1 (Distinctive facial features, short stature, and upper limb abnormalities)

Autosomal dominant Robinow syndrome 3 (DRS3) is a genetic disorder characterized by mesomelia, genital hypoplasia, and distinctive facial features such as frontal bossing, prominent eyes, and a depressed nasal bridge. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, meaning that a single copy of the defective gene is sufficient to cause the disorder. The DVL3 gene on chromosome 3q27 has been identified as the cause of this condition.

Smith Magenis syndrome is a chromosomal deletion syndrome that affects many parts of the body. It is characterized by mild-to-moderate infantile hypotonia, minor skeletal anomalies, prepubertal short stature, brachydactyly, ophthalmologic and otolaryngologic abnormalities, peripheral neuropathy, developmental delay, cognitive impairment, and behavioral abnormalities. The syndrome has a material basis in a 3.7-Mb interstitial deletion in chromosome 17p11.2 or sometimes by mutations in the RAI1 gene in the same region. It is also known as 17p11.2 microdeletion syndrome and chromosome 17p11.2 deletion syndrome.

dextro looped transposition of the great arteries is a type of congenital heart disease.
It is characterized by an abnormality in which the aorta arises from the right ventricle instead of the left, and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle instead of the right. This condition can make it difficult for the heart to pump blood effectively and can lead to serious complications if left untreated. It is also known as D-TGA or isolated ventriculoarterial discordance.

Cleft lip and palate, also known as orofacial clefting, is a congenital abnormality that occurs when the upper lip and/or the roof of the mouth (palate) do not form properly during fetal development. Cleft lip and palate can occur alone or in combination with other birth defects such as ectodermal dysplasia syndrome, which is a type of autosomal recessive disease that affects the ectodermal system, including teeth, hair, skin, and nails. Ectodermal dysplasia syndrome can cause various symptoms such as cleft lip and palate, hypodontia (missing teeth), anodontia (no teeth), microdontia (small teeth), syndactyly (webbing between fingers), palmoplantar hyperkeratosis (thickening of the skin on the hands and feet), onychodysplasia (abnormal nail growth), and sparse hair. Cleft lip and palate can also occur in other types of ectodermal dysplasia syndrome, such as Margarita type of ectodermal dysplasia, Zlotogora-Zilberman-Tenenbaum syndrome, cleft lip/palate-syndactyly-pili torti syndrome, and syndactyly-ectodermal dysplasia-cleft/lip palate.
Congenital diarrhea is a type of physical disorder characterized by frequent, loose, or liquid bowel movements where the disease has its basis in some abnormality of prenatal development or birth.

Microvillus inclusion disease is a type of autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by onset of intractable life-threatening watery diarrhea during infancy, lack of microvilli on the surface of enterocytes, and occurrence of intracellular vacuolar structures containing microvilli. It has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutation in the MYO5B gene on chromosome 18q21. The disease is also known by several other names, including congenital diarrhea, familial protracted diarrhea, and intractable diarrhea of infancy.

Congenital diarrhea 5 with tufting enteropathy is a type of autosomal recessive disease that affects the intestinal epithelium. It is characterized by persistent diarrhea, villous atrophy, and focal epithelial tufts in the duodenum and jejunum. The condition has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the EPCAM gene on chromosome 2p21. It is also known by other names such as DIAR5, congenital diarrhea 5 with tufting enteropathy, congenital familial intractable diarrhea with epithelial or epithelium abnormalities, and tufting enteropathy.

Congenital Secretory Sodium Diarrhea (CSND8) is a type of secretory diarrhea that has a genetic basis and is caused by mutations in the SLC9A3 gene on chromosome 5p15. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, which means it is passed down through generations with a higher chance for individuals who have two copies of the mutated gene (homozygous). CSND8 affects the function of the intestinal epithelium and results in abnormal secretion of sodium and water, leading to diarrhea. It is also known as DIAR8.
