Congenital malabsorptive diarrhea 4 is a type of congenital diarrhea that has material basis in mutations in the gene encoding neurogenin-3 (NEUROG3) on chromosome 10q21.3. It is characterized by chronic unremitting malabsorptive diarrhea and profound dysgenesis of the enteroendocrine cells. The condition has exact synonyms including congenital malabsorptive diarrhea due to paucity of enteroendocrine cells, congenital malabsorptive diarrhoea 4, enteric anendcrinosis and other similar terms.

Congenital diarrhea 6, also known as chronic diarrhea due to guanylate cyclase 2C overactivity or congenital diarrhoea 6, is a type of autosomal dominant disease. It is characterized by mild, early-onset chronic diarrhea that has a material basis in heterozygous mutation in the GUCY2C gene on chromosome 12p12.

Congenital Secretory Sodium Diarrhea 3, also known as Congenital Secretory Sodium Diarrhoea 3, is a type of autosomal recessive disorder that is characterized by diarrhea due to an abnormality in prenatal development or birth. It has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the SPINT2 gene on chromosome 19q13. The condition can be diagnosed through a combination of genetic testing, clinical examination, and laboratory tests to assess electrolyte levels, such as sodium and potassium. Treatment typically involves managing symptoms with dietary changes and medications to regulate fluid and electrolyte balance. In some cases, surgery may be necessary to address any underlying abnormalities in the gastrointestinal tract.

EEC syndrome, also known as Ectrodactyly, Ectodermal Dysplasia, and Cleft Lip-Palate (EDEC) syndrome, is a genetic disorder that affects the development of the skin, hair, nails, teeth, sweat glands, and outer ear. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, which means that a single copy of the gene can cause the condition to be expressed. EEC syndrome has multiple synonyms including Rudiger syndrome, Walker-Clodius syndrome, ectrodactyly, ectodermal dysplasia, and cleft lip-palate (EDEC) syndrome, and it can also be referred to as Ectrodactyly, Ectodermal Dysplasia, and Cleft Lip-Palate (EDEC) syndrome. It is essential to consult a medical professional for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.

Ectrodactyly, ectodermal dysplasia, and cleft lip palate syndrome 3 (EEC syndrome 3) is a genetic disorder that is characterized by the absence of the central parts of the hands and feet, resulting in split-hand/foot malformation. This condition also includes ectodermal dysplasia, which affects the development of skin, hair, nails, and sweat glands, as well as cleft lip with or without cleft palate. EEC syndrome 3 is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, meaning that a single copy of the faulty gene is enough to cause the disorder. It is caused by mutations in the TP63 gene, which is located on chromosome 3q28.

ECTD is a group of genetic disorders that affect the development of skin, hair, nails, and teeth. It is caused by mutations in certain genes on chromosome 7 and can be inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. The most common form of ECTD is ectrodactyly, which is characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of fingers or toes. Other features of ECTD include cleft lip and/or palate, abnormal bone growth, and abnormal skin pigmentation. There are several subtypes of ECTD, including ectrodactyly ectodermal dysplasia and cleft lip palate syndrome 1 (EEC1) which is one of the most severe forms. Treatment for ECTD typically involves surgery to correct abnormalities in bone growth and cleft lip or palate, as well as speech therapy and other supportive care.

Adult-onset autosomal dominant demyelinating leukodystrophy, also known as Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease type 4, is a type of leukodystrophy that affects the brain and spinal cord. It is characterized by onset in the fourth or fifth decade of life, with symptoms such as autonomic abnormalities, pyramidal and cerebellar dysfunction, and symmetric demyelination of the CNS. The disease has a material basis in heterozygous tandem genomic duplication resulting in an extra copy of the LMNB1 gene on chromosome 5q. It is also referred to as adult-onset autosomal dominant leukodystrophy and late-onset type Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease.

Hypomyelinating leukodystrophy (HLD) is a type of leukodystrophy characterized by improper formation of the myelin sheath in the central nervous system, resulting in T2 hyperintensity and variable T1 signal on magnetic resonance imaging. It has the exact synonym HLD.

Hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 2, also known as Pelizaeus-Merzbacher-like disease type 1 (PMLD1) and HLD2, is a genetic disorder characterized by autosomal recessive inheritance. It is caused by mutations in the GJC2 gene on chromosome 1q42, which encodes a protein involved in myelin formation.
Patients with hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 2 experience a range of symptoms, including nystagmus, impaired motor development, ataxia, choreoathetotic movements, dysarthria, and progressive spasticity.
There is no cure for hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 2, but treatments are available to manage the symptoms and improve quality of life. These may include physical therapy, speech therapy, medications to control seizures or muscle stiffness, and assistive devices such as wheelchairs or walkers.
It is important for individuals with hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 2 to work closely with their healthcare providers to develop an individualized treatment plan that addresses their specific needs and goals.

hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 10 is a type of autosomal recessive disease characterized by progressive postnatal microcephaly, severely delayed psychomotor development and hypomyelination that has material basis in homozygous mutation in the PYCR2 gene on chromosome 1q42.

Hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 4, also known as HLD4, is a type of autosomal recessive disease. It is characterized by hypotonia, nystagmus, psychomotor developmental delay, and severe hypomyelinating leukoencephalopathy that has a material basis in homozygous mutation in the HSPD1 gene on chromosome 2q33. It is also known by other names such as MitCHAP60 disease, Pelizaeus-Merzbacher-like disease due to HSPD1 mutation, and mitochondrial HSP60 chaperonopathy.

hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 3 is a type of autosomal recessive disease characterized by early infantile onset of global developmental delay, lack of development, lack of speech acquisition, and peripheral spasticity associated with decreased myelination in the central nervous system. It has material basis in homozygous mutation in the AIMP1 gene on chromosome 4q24. It also has the exact synonym HLD3 and Pelizaeus-Merzbacher-like disease due to AIMP1 mutation.

Hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 9 is a type of autosomal recessive disease. It is characterized by delayed psychomotor development, spasticity, and nystagmus starting in the first year of life. The condition has a material basis in compound heterozygous mutation in the RARS gene on chromosome 5q34. It also has the exact synonym HLD9 and RARS-related autosomal recessive hypomyelinating leukodystrophy.

Hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 11 is a type of autosomal recessive disease in which the genetic material is passed from one generation to another with a lower probability than other types of inheritance.

Hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 5 (HLD5) is a rare genetic disorder that affects the brain and spinal cord. It is an autosomal recessive disease, meaning that it requires the inheritance of two copies of the faulty gene (one from each parent) to develop the condition. H

Hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 7, also known as HLD7 or TACH syndrome, is a type of autosomal recessive disease characterized by childhood onset progressive motor decline manifesting as spasticity, ataxia, tremor, and cerebellar signs. It also includes mild cognitive regression and has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the POLR3A gene on chromosome 10q22. This condition is also known by several other synonyms, including ataxia-delayed dentition-hypomyelination syndrome, odontoleukodystrophy, dentoleukoencephalopathy, hypomyelination-cerebellar atrophy-hypoplasia of the corpus callosum syndrome, leukodystrophy with oligodontia, and leukoencephalopathy-ataxia-hypodontia-hypomyelination syndrome. Additionally, it can also be known as tremor-ataxia-central hypomyelination syndrome.

Hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 13, also known as HLD13, is a type of autosomal recessive disease characterized by delayed psychomotor development, axial hypotonia, and spasticity. It has a material basis in homozygous mutation in the C11ORF73 gene on chromosome 11q14.

hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 12 is a type of autosomal recessive disease characterized by severely delayed or even lack of psychomotor development that becomes apparent in the first months of life, acquired microcephaly and delayed myelination. It has a material basis in homozygous mutation in the VPS11 gene on chromosome 11q23. The disease is also known as HLD12.

Hypomyelinating leukodystrophy 8, also known as HLD8, is a type of autosomal recessive disease that affects the central nervous system. It is characterized by early onset cerebellar ataxia and mild intellectual disabilities, along with diffuse hypomyelination in the brain and spinal cord. Additionally, some individuals with HLD8 may also experience variable development of oligodontia (the absence of teeth) and/or hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This condition is caused by compound heterozygous mutations in the POLR3B gene on chromosome 12q23, which provides a material basis for its autosomal recessive inheritance.

Hypomyelinating leukodystrophy type 6, also known as H-ABC or HLD6, is a genetic disorder that affects the development of the brain and spinal cord. It is characterized by delayed motor development and gait instability in infancy or early childhood, followed by extrapyramidal movement disorders, progressive spastic tetraplegia, ataxia, hypomyelination, cerebellar atrophy, and putamen atrophy or disappearance. This condition is caused by mutations in the TUBB4A gene located on chromosome 19p13. It is an autosomal dominant disorder, which means that it can be passed down through generations with a high chance of being inherited when one parent carries the gene.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability, type Lubs (also known as MECP2 duplication syndrome) is a genetic condition that affects males and characterized by moderate to profound intellectual disability, infantile hypotonia, mild dysmorphic features, poor speech development, autistic features, seizures, progressive spasticity, and recurrent infections. The condition has a material basis in duplication or triplication of the MECP2 gene on chromosome Xq28. Other synonyms for this condition include Lubs X-linked mental retardation syndrome, MECP2 duplication syndrome, MRXSL, X-linked intellectual disability-hypotonia-recurrent infections syndrome, and mental retardation, X-linked, syndromic, Lubs type.

Mehmo Syndrome is a rare genetic condition that affects males and is characterized by severe intellectual disability, epilepsy, microcephaly, hypogonadism and obesity. It is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner, which means that the gene responsible for the condition is located on the X chromosome and requires two copies to be expressed (one from each parent). Males with one copy of the gene have a 50% chance of inheriting the disorder, while females typically have only one functional X chromosome and are therefore carriers. The syndrome has been named after its discoverer, Dr. Mehmet Ozdogan.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability (Snyder type) is a rare genetic disorder that affects brain development and causes mild to profound intellectual disability. It is characterized by facial asymmetry, marfanoid habitus, asthenic habitus, unsteady gait, thickened lower lip, nasal dysarthic speech, narrow or cleft palate, osteoporosis, kyphoscoliosis, long great toes, short stature, pectus carinatum, and myopia. The disorder has a material basis in mutation of the SMS gene on chromosome Xp22. It is also known as Snyder-Robinson mental retardation syndrome (SRS), Snyder-Robinson syndrome, and mental retardation, X-linked, Snyder-Robinson type. Additionally, it can be referred to as spermine synthase deficiency.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability 17 is a type of syndromic X-linked intellectual disability that is characterized by global developmental delay, delayed motor development, lack of speech development, intellectual disability, alacrima and in some patients achalasia and/or anisocoria. It has a material basis in variation in the chromosome region Xp21.1-p11.23. It has exact synonyms such as X-linked mental retardation with alacrima and achalasia, intellectual disability-alacrima-achalasia syndrome, and mental retardation, X-linked, syndromic 17.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability 12, also known as Wilson's Syndrome, is a rare genetic condition characterized by severe intellectual deficit, mutism, epilepsy, growth retardation or failure and recurrent infections. It has a material basis in variations in the chromosome region Xp11. This syndrome is X-linked, meaning that it is inherited from mothers to their sons more commonly than from fathers to daughters due to the way that the X chromosome is passed down through families.

Prieto Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects both males and females, but it is more severe in males. It is characterized by intellectual disability, facial dysmorphism, patella luxation, clinodactyly, subcortical cerebral atrophy, and abnormal growth of the teeth. The syndrome has a material basis in variations in the chromosome region Xp11-q21. It is also known as Prieto-Badia-Mulas syndrome or X-linked intellectual disability-dysmorphism-cerebral atrophy syndrome.

This is a description of Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability hedera type. It is characterized by mild to moderate mental retardation and epilepsy, which is caused by mutations in the ATP6AP2 gene on chromosome Xp11. It has been given the name MRXE.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability Najm type, also known as SXID Najm, is a type of syndromic X-linked intellectual disability characterized by severe intellectual disability, microcephaly with pontine and cerebellar hypoplasia that has a material basis in heterozygous mutation or deletion in the CASK gene on chromosome Xp11. It is also known as MICPCH, X-linked intellectual disability-microcephaly-pontocerebellar hypoplasia syndrome, and mental retardation and microcephaly with pontine and cerebellar hypoplasia.

syndromic X-linked intellectual disability 7 is a rare genetic disorder that affects individuals with an X chromosome. It is characterized by intellectual deficit, obesity, hypogonadism, and tapering fingers. The syndrome has a material basis in variations in the chromosome region Xp11.3-q22.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability, also known as Claes Jensen type, is a syndromic form of intellectual disability that results from mutations in the KDM5C gene located on the Xp11 chromosome. It is characterized by severe intellectual deficits, variable clinical manifestations, and has material basis in some X-linked recessive inheritance. This type of intellectual disability also has exact synonyms such as MRXSCJ, MRXSJ, and mental retardation, X-linked, syndromic, Claes-Jensen type. Additionally, it can be caused by mutations in the JARID1C gene, resulting in syndromic X-linked intellectual disability due to JARID1C mutation or syndromic X-linked mental retardation JARID1C-related.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability type 10, also known as HSD17B10 deficiency or MRXS10, is a genetic condition characterized by mild intellectual impairment, choreoathetosis (a movement disorder), and abnormal behavior. It is caused by a mutation in the HSD17B10 gene on the Xp11.22 chromosome. This condition has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, which means that to develop the condition, a person must inherit two copies of the mutated gene, one from each parent. Symptoms typically appear in early childhood and can include developmental delays, motor skill issues, and behavioral problems. Treatment may involve medications to manage symptoms, physical therapy, and speech therapy.

This is a description of Turner Syndrome, which is a type of X-linked intellectual disability. It is characterized by moderate to severe intellectual deficit in boys and moderate intellectual deficit in girls, macrocephaly (large head size), and holoprosencephaly (merging of the two nasal cavities into one) in some cases. The syndrome has a material basis in mutation of the HUWE1 gene on chromosome Xp11.22. It is also known as Brooks-Wisniewski-Brown Syndrome, MRXST, X-linked intellectual disability, Brooks type, mental retardation and macrocephaly syndrome, and mental retardation, X-linked syndromic, Turner type.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability, Siderius type is a rare genetic condition that affects brain development and causes mild to moderate intellectual disability. People with this condition may also have certain physical characteristics such as a long face, a broad nasal tip, cleft lip/palate, preaxial polydactyly (an extra finger or toe on the hand), and cryptorchidism (undescended testicles). The condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern, which means that it is passed down through the mother's side of the family. It has been linked to a mutation in the PHF8 gene located on the Xp11.22 chromosome region.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability, also known as Shrimpton's syndrome, is a rare genetic condition characterized by severe mental retardation, microcephaly (small head size), speech delay, and variable short stature. The condition has a material basis in variations in the chromosomal region Xq12-q21.31. It is also known as MRXS9 and mental retardation, X-linked, syndromic 9 (MRTXS9).

Wilson Turner Syndrome (WTS) is a type of X-linked recessive disease that results in intellectual disability, truncal obesity, gynecomastia, hypogonadism, dysmorphic facial features, and short stature. It is characterized by hemizygous mutation in the LAS1L gene on chromosome Xq12.

Miles Carpenter Syndrome is a type of intellectual disability that affects both males and females, but it is more common in males. It is characterized by severe intellectual deficit, microcephaly, exotropia (drifting of the eyes), distal muscle wasting, and low digital arches. The syndrome has a genetic basis and is caused by variations in the X chromosome region Xq13-q22.

The corpus callosum agenesis intellectual disability coloboma micrognathia syndrome, also known as Graham-Cox syndrome or MRXS28, is a type of syndromic X-linked intellectual disability. It is characterized by the absence of the corpus callosum, intellectual disability, ocular coloboma, micrognathia, sensorineural hearing loss, skeletal anomalies, and short stature. This condition has a genetic basis and is caused by mutations in the IGBP1 gene on chromosome Xq13.1.

syndromic x linked intellectual disability 34 is a type of syndromic x linked intellectual disability that is characterized by delayed psychomotor development, intellectual disability, impaired speech, dysmorphic facial features, and mild structural brain abnormalities, including thickening of the corpus callosum. It has material basis in mutation in the NONO gene on chromosome Xq13. This condition is also known by other names such as MRXS34, MRXSML, macrocephaly-intellectual disability-left ventricular non compaction syndrome, mental retardation, X-linked, syndromic 34, and syndromic X-linked mental retardation Mircsof-Langouet type.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability, also known as Abidi type, is a genetic condition that affects boys and results in intellectual disability along with the presence of specific physical traits. These physical traits may include short stature, small head circumference, a sloping forehead, hearing loss, abnormally shaped ears, and small testes. The exact cause of this condition is not fully understood but it's linked to variations in the chromosomal region Xq13.2. It is important to note that while this disorder can cause significant challenges for individuals affected by it, early intervention and support services can make a big difference in their quality of life.

The syndromic X-linked intellectual disability, also known as Chudley-Schwartz type, is characterized by moderate intellectual disability, seizures, dysmorphic facial features, and in some older patients, slowly progressive unsteady gait and progressive weakness. This condition has a genetic basis, specifically variations in the chromosomal region Xq21.33-q23.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability nascimento type is a syndrome characterized by intellectual disability and several physical features. The defining features of this syndrome include a large head, synophrys (a deep-set look in the eyes), prominent supraorbital ridges, almond-shaped eyes, a wide mouth, myxedematous appearance, hirsutism (excessive hair growth), abnormal hair whorls, micropenis, and onychodystrophy. These features are due to mutations in the UBE2A gene located on the X chromosome at position Xq24.

This syndrome has also been known as X-linked intellectual disability-nail dystrophy-seizures syndrome and mental retardation, X-linked syndromic, Nascimento-type.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability 14, also known as XPMD14, is a genetic condition that affects males and characterized by mild to severe intellectual disability, autistic features, slender build, poor musculature, long thin face, high-arched palate, high nasal bridge, pectus deformities. It is caused by mutations in the UPF3B gene on chromosome Xq24.

Syndromic X-linked intellectual disability (Raymond type) is a condition characterized by intellectual disability and a distinctive physical appearance, known as marfanoid habitus. It is caused by mutations in the ZDHHC9 gene on the X chromosome, specifically at the q26.1 location. This condition has been previously referred to as MRXSR, X-linked syndromic intellectual developmental disorder Raymond type, and mental retardation, X-linked syndromic, Raymond type.

Christianson syndrome is a type of syndromic X-linked intellectual disability. It is characterized by severe developmental delay, intellectual disability, microcephaly, impaired speech, ataxia, hypotonia, and early-onset seizures. The condition has a material basis in mutation of the SLC9A6 gene on chromosome Xq26. It has exact synonyms such as MRXSCH, X-linked Angelman-like syndrome, X-linked intellectual disability, South African type, and X-linked intellectual disability-craniofacial dysmorphism-epilepsy-ophthalmoplegia-cerebellar atrophy syndrome. It's characterized by several symptoms including manic-depressive psychosis, pyramidal signs, and macroorchidism (excessive growth of the male reproductive organs). The condition has a genetic basis, specifically mutations in the MECP2 gene on chromosome Xq28. It's also known as Lindsay-Burn syndrome, MRXS13, PPM-X, X-linked mental retardation 79 and mental retardation with psychosis, pyramidal signs, and macroorchidism.

x linked intellectual disability cardiomegaly congestive heart failure syndrome is a type of syndromic x linked intellectual disability. This means that it is caused by a mutation on the X chromosome and can lead to intellectual disability and other physical characteristics. Cardiomegaly, or enlargement of the heart, is one such characteristic, as well as congestive heart failure. Syndromic x linked intellectual disability typically affects males more severely than females due to the X-linked inheritance pattern. Other symptoms may include seizures, large joint contractures, and abnormal positioning of the thumbs.

Yes, Martin-Probst Syndrome is a type of X-linked intellectual disability that presents with severe bilateral deafness, intellectual disability, umbilical hernia, and abnormal dermatoglyphics. It is characterized by variation on the X chromosome. The syndrome has also been known as mental retardation, X-linked, syndromic, Martin-Probst type.

Griscelli Syndrome is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder that affects the skin and hair. It causes silvery-gray hair and pigmentation problems in the skin. The condition has also been referred to as Chediak-Higashi-like syndrome, Griscelli-Prunieras syndrome, or partial albinism-immunodeficiency syndrome.

Griscelli syndrome type 1 is a rare genetic disorder that affects the skin and nervous system. It is characterized by a silvery-gray sheen of the hair, hypopigmentation (lightening) of the skin, and neurological impairments without immune system deficiencies. The condition is caused by mutations in the MYO5A gene on chromosome 15q21.2. It has been previously known by other names such as GS1, Griscelli syndrome with neurological impairment, Griscelli syndrome, cutaneous and neurological type, Griscelli-Prunieras syndrome type 1, and hypopigmentation-neurologic impairment syndrome.

Griscelli Syndrome Type 2, also known as GS2, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the following symptoms:

1. A silvery-gray sheen on the hair and skin (hypopigmentation)
2. Immune system dysfunction with or without neurological impairment
3. Material basis in a mutation of the RAB27A gene on chromosome 15q21.3

GS2 is different from Griscelli Syndrome Type 1, which lacks the hypopigmentation. Both types have an increased risk of developing hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH), a life-threatening condition that occurs when the body's immune system becomes overactive and attacks healthy cells and tissues.

GS2 has also been referred to as other names, including Griscelli syndrome with hemophagocytic syndrome, Griscelli-Prunieras syndrome type 2, PAID syndrome (pyloritis, aphthous ulcers, immune dysregulation, and developmental disabilities), hypopigmentation-immunodeficiency with or without neurologic impairment syndrome, and partial albinism and immunodeficiency syndrome.

It is important to note that Griscelli Syndrome Type 2 may require regular monitoring by a healthcare professional due to the potential risks associated with HLH and other complications related to immune system dysfunction.

Griscelli Syndrome Type 3 is a rare genetic disorder that affects the skin and hair. It is characterized by an isolated silvery-gray sheen in the hair and hypopigmentation of the skin, with a mutation in either the MLPH or MYO5A gene. This condition has also been referred to as Griscelli-Prunieras Syndrome Type 3. It is essential to consult a healthcare professional for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan.

Isolated microphthalmia 6 is a type of autosomal recessive disease where the eye size is reduced to the posterior segment, extreme hyperopia and short axial length. This condition has material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the PRSS56 gene on chromosome 2q37. It also has an exact synonym MCOP6 and is sometimes referred to as posterior nonsyndromic microphthalmia.

Isolated microphthalmia 4, also known as MCOP4, is a type of monogenic disease. It is characterized by the presence of an eye with a small or absent lens, and it can lead to blindness if not treated properly. The condition has a basis in a mutation in the GDF6 gene on chromosome 8q22.

Isolated microphthalmia 5 is a type of autosomal recessive disease that affects vision. It causes posterior microphthalmia, hypermetropia, night blindness, decreased visual acuity, reduced macular reflex, scleral thickening, impaired rod and cone responses on ERG, foveoschisis, and in some patients, retinal pigment epithelium atrophy, arteriolar attenuation, angle-closure glaucoma, and optic disc drusen. It has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the MFRP gene on chromosome 11q23. It is also known as microphthalmia-retinitis pigmentosa-foveoschisis-optic disc drusen syndrome and posterior microphthalmia with retinitis pigmentosa, foveoschisis, and optic disc drusen.

Isolated microphthalmia 7, also known as MCOP7, is a type of autosomal dominant disease characterized by unilateral microphthalmia that has a material basis in mutations in the GDF3 gene on chromosome 12p13.

Isolated microphthalmia 2 is a type of autosomal recessive disease characterized by bilateral profound microphthalmia without associated anomalies and with normal intelligence, which has a material basis in homozygous mutation in the CHX10 gene on chromosome 14q24. Another name for this condition is MCOP2.

Isolated microphthalmia type 1 is a genetic disorder that is passed down through families (autosomal recessive inheritance). It affects the development of the eye and can cause small or absent eyes. The gene responsible for this condition is located on chromosome 14q32. Isolated microphthalmia type 1 is also known as MCOP1.

Isolated microphthalmia 8 is a genetic disorder that affects the development of the eyes. It is caused by a mutation in the ALDH1A3 gene, which is located on chromosome 15q26. The condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, which means that a person must inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the disorder. It results in bilateral severe microphthalmia, which is the underdevelopment or absence of the eyes. The condition is also known as MCOP8.

Isolated microphthalmia 3 is a type of autosomal recessive disease where the individual has clinical anophthalmia and/or microphthalmia. It has a material basis in compound heterozygous mutation in the RAX gene on chromosome 18q21. Another term for this condition is MCOP3.

Hereditary neuropathy with liability to pressure palsies is a type of autosomal dominant disease characterized by the inheritance of peroneal muscle weakness, peripheral neuropathy, hyporeflexia, and segmental demyelination/remyelination. It has been described as having a material basis in deletion or point mutation of the PMP22 gene on chromosome 17p12. The condition is also known by several other synonyms including HNPP, current pressure-sensitive neuropathy, familial recurrent polyneuropathy, heterozygous microdeletion 17p11.2p12, potato-grubbing palsy, tomaculous neuropathy, and tulip-bulb digger's palsy.

Norrie disease is a type of genetic disorder that affects the retina and can cause blindness. It is also sometimes accompanied by mental and hearing issues. The condition is caused by mutations in the NDP gene on the X chromosome, which is why it is considered an X-linked recessive disease.

Leri-Weill dyschondrosteosis, also known as Leri-Weill dysplasia or short stature with brachydactyly and clinodactyly, is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal growth of the forearms and lower legs, leading to short stature. It is caused by mutations in either the SHOX gene or its downstream regulatory domain, resulting in reduced expression of the SHOX protein. The condition may also include abnormal alignment of the wrist (Madelung deformity), which can affect hand and finger development. Leri-Weill dyschondrosteosis is inherited in an autosomal manner, with both alleles being necessary for expression of the disorder.

User, Developmental and epileptic encephalopathy 9 (DEE9) is indeed a type of developmental and epileptic encephalopathy with a genetic basis. It is characterized by seizure onset in infancy and mild to severe intellectual impairment in females that has a material basis in heterozygous mutation in the gene encoding protocadherin-19 (PCDH19) on chromosome Xq22. It is also known by several other names, such as DEE, EIEE, Juberg Hellman syndrome, and early infantile epileptic encephalopathy 9 or early infantile female-limited epileptic encephalopathy. Additionally, it may be referred to as female restricted epilepsy with mental retardation.

Osteoporosis pseudoglioma syndrome is a type of autosomal recessive disease characterized by congenital or infancy-onset blindness, very low bone mass, decreased trabecular bone volume, severe juvenile-onset osteoporosis and spontaneous fractures, pseudoglioma, microphthalmia. It has a material basis in homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the LRP5 gene on chromosome 11q13. It is also known as OPPG and the ocular form of osteogenesis imperfecta.

Annular pancreas is a medical condition that affects the pancreas, specifically by causing it to form a ring around the second portion of the duodenum. This can lead to difficulties in digestion and other health problems. It has been linked to autosomal dominant inheritance, meaning that it can be passed down through generations of a family. Additionally, duodenal stenosis is often present in individuals with annular pancreas.

pemphigus vulgaris is a type of pemphigus characterized by autosomal dominant blisters and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes caused by autoantibodies to intercellular cement substance. It has an exact synonym of familial pemphigus vulgaris.

Pierson syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects many organ systems in the body. It is caused by mutations in the LAMB2 gene, which is located on chromosome 3p21. The condition can cause kidney problems, eye abnormalities, and other health issues. Symptoms may include proteinuria (excessive protein in the urine), microcoria (small kidneys), ciliary muscle atrophy, and abnormal eye development with lens-shape, retinal, and corneal anomalies. Additionally, there is often a lack of pupillary dilator muscle in the iris. Treatment options may include medications to manage symptoms and prevent complications.

Potocki-Lupski Syndrome (PLS) is a rare chromosomal disorder that occurs due to the duplication of a region on chromosome 17p11.2. It is characterized by various developmental and physical abnormalities, including:

* Hypotonia (low muscle tone)
* Failure to thrive (growth and development difficulties)
* Mental retardation
* Pervasive Developmental Disorders (e.g., autism spectrum disorder or ADHD)
* Congenital anomalies (birth defects)

It is also known as 17p11.2 microduplication syndrome, chromosome 17p11.2 duplication syndrome, and trisomy 17p11.2. It is important to note that the severity of symptoms can vary greatly among individuals affected by PLS.

Autosomal recessive pseudohypoaldosteronism type 1 is a medical condition that is caused by mutations in one of three genes: SCNN1A, SCNN1B, or SCNN1G. These genes encode subunits of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC), which plays a role in regulating salt and water balance in the body.

When individuals have autosomal recessive pseudohypoaldosteronism type 1, they may experience enal salt wasting and high concentrations of sodium in their sweat, stool, and saliva. This condition can lead to a range of complications, including electrolyte imbalances, dehydration, and an increased risk of developing kidney stones.

Autosomal recessive pseudohypoaldosteronism type 1 is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning that an individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to develop the condition. There is no cure for this condition, but it can be managed through dietary changes and medications that help to balance electrolyte levels and prevent complications.

Autosomal dominant pseudohypoaldosteronism type 1 is a condition that can be inherited from one's parents. It results in the body not responding well to aldosterone, which can lead to low potassium levels and other health problems. It has a genetic basis and is caused by mutations in the NR3C2 gene on chromosome 4q31. The condition is also known as PHA1A or autosomal dominant PHA 1.

Right atrial isomerism is a rare congenital heart disease characterized by an atrioventricular septal defect with a common atrium and univentricular AV connection, total anomalous pulmonary drainage, and transposition or malposition of the great arteries. It has a material basis in homozygous mutation in the GDF1 gene on chromosome 19p12. The disease is also known as Ivemark syndrome or asplenia with cardiovascular anomalies.

Septooptic dysplasia is a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of the optic nerve, pituitary gland, and midline brain structures. It is caused by mutations in the HESX1 gene on chromosome 3p14. The condition is characterized by the triad of optic nerve hypoplasia, pituitary gland hypoplasia, and midline brain defects. It has also been referred to as De Morsier syndrome, SOD (Septo-Optic Dysplasia), and septo-optic dysplasia.
